flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: This recipe is great for holidays or any other day. It's easy and fun to make, and the little ones will go crazy for them; I know we do.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This recipe is great for holidays or any other day. It's easy and fun to make, and the little ones will go crazy for them; I know we do.

Relevant parts
  • 1/3 cup butter (or margarine)
  • 1/2 cup milk (or evaporated)
  • 1 cup coconut
  • 4 teaspoons cocoa
  • 3 cups oatmeal
  • 1 1/2 cup sugar
Tools
  • Cookie sheet or large plate
  • Large mixing bowl
  • Measuring cup
  • Pot
  • Teaspoon
  • Whisk
  • Wooden spoon

parts.notes: can substitue half brown sugar; we did

lines.text: First, you add both the oatmeal and coconut together in a large mixing bowl, and set aside.
lines.text_raw: First, you add both the oatmeal and coconut together in a large mixing bowl, and set aside.

lines.text: Next, bring out your pot and add your milk (or condensed, your preference), butter (or margarine), and your sugar. For ours we used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar.
lines.text_raw: Next, bring out your pot and add your milk (or condensed, your preference), butter (or margarine), and your sugar. For ours we used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar.

lines.text: Add your cocoa, then put on stove, on low heat (DO NOT BOIL). Whisk or stir until the mixture becomes smooth so all the sugar and cocoa has dissolved.
lines.text_raw: Add your cocoa, then put on stove, on low heat (DO NOT BOIL). Whisk or stir until the mixture becomes smooth so all the sugar and cocoa has dissolved.

lines.text: Add your pot of dissolved ingredients to your large mixing bowl of dry ingredients of oatmeal and coconut. Mix, mush, and fold until it's thoroughly mixed.
lines.text_raw: Add your pot of dissolved ingredients to your large mixing bowl of dry ingredients of oatmeal and coconut. Mix, mush, and fold until it's thoroughly mixed.

lines.text: Lastly, you will want to spoon your mixture into bite-sized cookies.  I used 2 teaspoons cupped together to form the style and shape of cookie I wanted.  Then place them on a cookie sheet with wax paper on it so they won't stick to the pan (everyone hates doing dishes).  Now you let them set. I like to put them in the fridge overnight for best results.
lines.text_raw: Lastly, you will want to spoon your mixture into bite-sized cookies.  I used 2 teaspoons cupped together to form the style and shape of cookie I wanted.  Then place them on a cookie sheet with wax paper on it so they won't stick to the pan (everyone hates doing dishes).  Now you let them set. I like to put them in the fridge overnight for best results.

guide.summary: Delicious no-bake coconut goodies that just melt in your mouth. One is never enough and they take just moments to make.
guide.title: Cocoa-Coconut No-Bake Cookies
